docs.lead_paragraph: John Branch of The New York Times and Dr. Robert A. Stern, a neuropsychologist and a co-director for the Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy, are answering questions Tuesday afternoon about C.T.E. and Branch's series ''Punched Out.'' The Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy, at the Boston University School of Medicine, was created in 2008 as a collaboration between the medical school and the Sports Legacy Institute, an organization devoted to addressing the issue of concussions in sport.

headline.main: Q. and A.: Responses From an Ex-Enforcer and an Expert

docs.abstract: Excerpts of readers Q&A with neuropsychologist Dr Robert A Stern, who is a co-director for Boston University's Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy, about former NHL enforcer Derek Boogaard and CTE. Photo (M).

docs.lead_paragraph: Who owns the bacteria swimming through your body: you, or the researcher who discovers it?
docs.abstract: Carl Zimmer Gray Matter column examines the host of ethical questions and dilemmas presented by new research in microbiology and on bacteria.
